questions.text: A patient addressing from Delhi presents with fever, arthralgia, and extensive petechial rash for 3 days. Lab investigations revealed a hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, a white blood cell count of 9000 cells/mm3, a platelet count of 20000 cells/mm3, and a prolonged bleeding time. The clotting time was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dengue

 

The patient with given symptoms and lab results, points out to diagnosis of dengue fever.

 

Dengue, aka Break Bone Fever

 

 

Shown below is an image of the rash in dengue:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malaria patients presents with clinical features like periodic bouts of fever with chills and rigors, followed by anemia, splenomegaly, and hepatomegaly.

 

Option C. Scrub typhus patients typically presents with a characteristic eschar, which is a punched-out ulcer covered with a blackened scab at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash. Here’s an image of the eschar.

 

 

Option D. Typhoid (enteric) fever presents with fever, abdominal pain, headache, chills, myalgia, malaise, diarrhea, sweating, nausea, and vomiting. Rose spots are classical, pink macules on the abdomen and the chest. Hepatosplenomegaly and relative bradycardia might be seen. The WBC count vary from normal to low.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of fever, arthralgia, petechial rash, and significant thrombocytopenia in a patient from an area where dengue is endemic should prompt immediate consideration of dengue fever, with prompt initiation of supportive care and monitoring for potential complications such as DHF or DSS.

questions.text: A photographer who recently returned from Africa presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and hemorrhagic manifestations. He died despite treatment, and an autopsy revealed intranuclear Torres bodies in the liver. Which of the following vaccines could have prevented it? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 17D

 

The above clinical vignette is suggestive of yellow fever and the use of 17D vaccine could have prevented this.

 

17D vaccine is a live-attenuated vaccine administered through the subcutaneous route. It is contraindicated in infants less than 9 months of age, in pregnancy, and in individuals with egg allergy.

 

Yellow fever is caused by flavivirus and is endemic to certain parts of Africa and America. It occurs in two patterns: the urban cycle and the sylvatic cycle. Aedes aegypti is the vector in the urban cycle, while Aedes africanus is responsible for transmission in the sylvatic cycle.

 

Patients present with acute onset fever, headache, and vomiting. Jaundice and hemorrhagic manifestations can also be present. Ultimately, hepatic or renal failure can result in death.

 

Torres bodies are intranuclear eosinophilic inclusion bodies in hepatocytes. These are rarely seen in yellow fever. To prevent the establishment of the disease in India, strict vaccination and quarantine protocols for travelers from endemic areas are enforced.

 

Other options:

 

Option B: Nakayama vaccine is used for immunization against Japanese encephalitis. Culex tritaeniorhynchus is the principal vector. There is a sudden onset of fever and vomiting, which later progresses to encephalitis. In India, it was first reported in Vellore and continues to be active in the country.

 

Option C. Weigl's vaccine is the earliest used vaccine against epidemic typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. The main foci of the disease are Europe, Africa, South America, and Asia. Kashmir is the endemic spot in India. Pediculus humans corporis (human body louse) is the vector. Symptoms include fever and chills. A characteristic rash on the trunk and limbs, sparing the face, palms, and soles, may also be seen.

 

Option D. Jeryl-Lynn strain of the mumps virus is used against the disease as a live-attenuated vaccine. It is contraindicated in pregnancy and individuals allergic to eggs. Mumps present as parotid swelling associated with fever and tenderness.

 

Educational Objective

 

The 17D vaccine could have prevented the yellow fever that led to the photographer's severe symptoms and death. This highlights the importance of appropriate vaccination before traveling to areas where yellow fever is endemic.

questions.text: What is an infrequent yet highly serious adverse outcome of clozapine that necessitates consistent monitoring?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Agranulocytosis

 

CLOZAPINE

 

  • Treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS)- Lack of response to at least two different antipsychotics, including at least one second-generation antipsychotic, given in adequate dosage and for an adequate duration (at least 4-6 weeks).
  • Clozapine is the drug of choice (DOC) in TRS.
  • Unique mechanism of action- More affinity for D4 than D2, hence causes minimal EPS.
  • Antipsychotic that causes max weight gain.
  • Clozapine is the only antipsychotic with antisuicide property.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suicidal tendency: Incorrect. Clozapine actually has the unique anti-suicidal property among antipsychotics. It reduces suicidal behavior in patients with schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorder.

 

Option C. Myocarditis: While clozapine-induced myocarditis is a recognized idiosyncratic reaction, it is much less common than agranulocytosis. It typically occurs within the first few weeks of therapy but does not require the same routine hematologic monitoring.

 

Option D. Cerebral bleeding: Not a known adverse effect of clozapine. Bleeding complications are not typically associated with antipsychotic use unless the patient is on anticoagulants or has thrombocytopenia due to another cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Side effects of clozapine

 

  • Life-threatening: Agranulocytosis (idiosyncratic), myocarditis (idiosyncratic), seizures (dose-dependent)
  • Sedation (most common), sialorrhea
  • Syncope, hypotension, tachycardia, nausea, vomiting
  • Weight gain, anticholinergic side effects
  • Due to the possibility of agranulocytosis, when a patient is on clozapine, ANC and TLC monitoring is required.
  • The regime of monitoring-
    • First 6 months- Once a week
    • Next 6 months- Once in two weeks
    • After 1 year- Once in four weeks, till clozapine is continued 
  • Stop clozapine, if WBC < 3000/dl or ANC < 1500/dl
  • Contraindications for clozapine use
    • WBC < 3500/dl
    • History of agranulocytosis on clozapine
    • Use of other bone marrow suppressants like carbamazepine

questions.text: A young girl has been experiencing repeated instances of yeast infections and respiratory virus infections since she was only 3 months old. Given her immune system's condition, which of the listed vaccines should not be administered to her? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Measles/MMR

 

Based on the information provided, the girl child has a history of recurrent yeast infections and respiratory virus infections since she was 3 months old. This suggests that she may have an underlying immunodeficiency.

 

In this scenario, the measles/MMR vaccine would be contraindicated due to the risk of causing a severe infection in an immunocompromised individual.

 

CONTRAINDICATIONS OF LIVE VACCINES –

 

  • Immunodeficient individuals (Symptomatic HIV infection) except BCG vaccine
  • Immunosuppressed individuals (patient with leukemia or patients on antimetabolites, steroids or radiation)
  • Pregnancy (except Yellow fever)

 

Additional Information

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Killed IPV (Inactivated Polio Vaccine): Safe for immunocompromised individuals as it does not contain live virus.

 

Option C. DPT (Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus): Safe for immunocompromised individuals as it is not a live vaccine.

 

Option D. TT/Td (Tetanus Toxoid/Tetanus and Diphtheria): Safe for immunocompromised individuals as it is not a live vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Live vaccines like Measles/MMR should not be administered to immunocompromised individuals due to the risk of severe infection. Instead, inactivated or subunit vaccines, which do not contain live pathogens, should be used.

questions.text: An investigation was conducted to evaluate the nutritional status of young children residing in both rural and urban regions. Among the participants, 30 children from rural areas and 20 children from urban areas were found to be malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Chi Square test

 

The Chi Square test can be used to determine whether there is a significant association or relationship between two categorical variables. In this case, the two variables are the nutritional status (malnourished or not malnourished) and the location (rural or urban), both of which are Qualitative characters.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paired T test:  is used when comparing the means of two related samples, such as before and after measurements for the same group.

 

Option C. Standard error of the mean:  is a measure of the variability of sample means.

 

Option D.  ANOVA:  is used to compare the means of three or more groups.

These tests are not appropriate for analyzing the relationship between two categorical variables as in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Chi Square test is the appropriate statistical test for evaluating the association between two categorical variables, such as nutritional status (malnourished vs. not malnourished) and location (rural vs. urban).

questions.text: What is the proper disposal method for a damaged vaccine vial according to biomedical waste management protocols? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Puncture proof blue bin 

 

Blue puncture proof container

 

Under BMW guidelines, Glassware and Metallic Body Implants are disposed in Cardboard boxes with blue colored marking/ puncture proof bins. These bins are specifically designed to safely handle glass and metallic body implants to prevent injury and ensure proper disposal.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented for evaluation. During the session, he was quite charming, and there is a history of him behaving nicely with family members. However, he often gets in fights with friends. He was also involved in multiple police cases. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antisocial personality

 

The description provided in the question fits the criteria for Antisocial Personality Disorder (ASPD). Key characteristics of ASPD include a disregard for others' rights, frequent conflicts with social norms, legal issues, and manipulative or deceitful behavior. This individual displays charm during sessions, which is common among people with antisocial personality, as they can be superficially charming and convincing. The fact that he is often involved in fights and has multiple police cases further supports the diagnosis of ASPD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Narcissistic personality: Narcissistic Personality Disorder is characterized by grandiosity, a constant need for admiration, and a lack of empathy. Individuals with this disorder often talk about themselves, praise themselves excessively, and have a sense of entitlement. This patient's behavior does not include any such characteristics; instead, it focuses on antisocial behaviors.

 

Option C. Schizotypal personality: Schizotypal Personality Disorder is marked by eccentric behavior, discomfort with close relationships, and cognitive or perceptual distortions. There is no evidence in the question indicating any such traits, such as odd beliefs, social anxiety, or unusual thinking.

 

Option D. Paranoid personality: Paranoid Personality Disorder involves a pervasive distrust and suspicion of others. People with this disorder frequently believe others are out to harm or deceive them. This patient shows no signs of suspiciousness or paranoia; his behavior is more aligned with antisocial conduct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antisocial Personality Disorder is characterized by a pattern of disregard for others' rights, often involving legal issues, deceitful behavior, and superficial charm.

questions.text: In a 10-year-old school child, which of the following vaccines is given as a part of the school immunization program? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) TT/Td vaccine

 

In the national immunization schedule, the TT/Td vaccine is given to children at 10 years & 16 years of age as part of the school immunization program.

 

Additional Information

 

Age Limits for Delayed Immunization in NIS, India

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measles Vaccine can be given till 5 years of age.

 

Option B. Rotavirus vaccines can be given till 12 years of age.

 

Option D. Hepatitis B vaccine can be given till 1 year of age.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

National Immunisation schedule (2023-24):

questions.text: What is the most important assessment based on the treatment given to the patient and their clinical management in a health care facility? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Process

 

Evaluation of "process" can assess a health care facility based on the treatment given to the patient and their clinical management.

 

The process of evaluation involves several steps, such as

 

  • Determining what needs to be evaluated
  • Establishing standards and criteria
  • Planning the methodology
  • Gathering information
  • Analyzing the results
  • Taking action
  • Re-evaluating

 

There are three types of evaluation: structure evaluation, process evaluation, and outcome evaluation.

 

  1. Evaluation of "structure": This is evaluation of whether facilities, equipment, manpower and organization meet a standard accepted by experts as good.
  2. Evaluation of "process": The process of medical care includes the problems of recognition, diagnostic procedures, treatment and clinical management, care and prevention. The way in which the various activities of the programme is carried out is evaluated by comparing with a predetermined standard. An objective and systematic way of evaluating the physician (or nurse) performance is known as "Medical (or nursing) Audit"
  3. Evaluation of "outcome": This is concerned with the end results, that is, whether persons using health services experience measurable benefits such as improved survival or reduced disability. The traditional outcome components are the "5 Ds" of ill-health, viz. disease, discomfort, dissatisfaction, disability and death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Outcome: Focuses on the end results of healthcare, such as improved health status and reduced disease and disability.

 

  • Not Correct: It measures the results of care, not the processes used to deliver it.

 

Option C. Structure: Examines the physical and organizational infrastructure, like facilities, equipment, and staffing.

 

  • Not Correct: It evaluates resources and infrastructure, not the actual delivery of care.

 

Option D. Input: Assesses resources required for healthcare, such as funding, manpower, and materials.

 

  • Not Correct: It looks at the resources used, not how care is delivered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "process" evaluation is the most relevant assessment for determining the quality of treatment and clinical management provided to patients in a healthcare facility. It focuses on the procedures and methods used in patient care, ensuring adherence to established standards and guidelines.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is suffering from selective mutism. He is most probably suffering from? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Childhood anxiety disorder

 

Selective mutism is an anxiety disorder where a child speaks in some settings (like home) but consistently remains silent in others (like school).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Childhood depression: Children with depression might withdraw but don't exhibit selective mutism.

 

Option B. Childhood psychosis: Psychosis presents with hallucinations or delusions, not selective mutism.

 

Option D. Hyperkinetic disorder: ADHD involves inattention or hyperactivity, not selective silence in specific scenarios.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Selective mutism is an anxiety disorder characterized by a child's consistent failure to speak in specific situations, despite being able to speak in others.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 3719.

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerve develops from second brachial arch? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Facial nerve

 

Branchial arches are also known as pharyngeal arches
 

The facial nerve is the nerve of the 2nd pharyngeal arch.

 

The facial nerve (seventh cranial nerve) is responsible for the motor innervation of the muscles of facial expression. Additionally, it provides taste sensation for the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and supplies parasympathetic fibers to the submandibular, sublingual, and lacrimal glands. The facial nerve is associated with the second brachial (or pharyngeal) arch.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve is the ninth cranial nerve (CN IX) arising from the medulla oblongata and is associated with the third brachial (or pharyngeal) arch. It supplies sensation to the posterior third of the tongue, the upper pharynx, and the tonsil. It also has motor functions for the stylopharyngeus muscle and provides parasympathetic fibers to the parotid gland.

 

Option B. Trigeminal nerve: The trigeminal nerve is the fifth cranial nerve (CN V) and is primarily a sensory nerve for the face, with a smaller motor component for the muscles of mastication. The nerve develops in association with the first brachial (or pharyngeal) arch. It divides into three primary branches: the ophthalmic, maxillary, and mandibular nerves.

 

Option D. Vagal nerve: The vagus nerve is the tenth cranial nerve (CN X). It has a wide distribution and serves multiple functions in the body. Its functions include supplying motor innervation to the muscles of the pharynx and larynx, providing sensory information from the external ear and parts of the pharynx, and carrying parasympathetic fibers to thoracic and abdominal viscera. The vagus nerve is associated with the fourth (and a contribution from the sixth) brachial (or pharyngeal) arch.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Years lost due to premature death
Years lost to poor quality of life

questions.text: The years of potential life lost could be attributed to? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Years lost due to premature death

 

Years of Potential Life Lost (YPLL)

 

Definition: YPLL is based on Years of life lost through premature death

 

Importance:

 

  • YPLL occurs before the age to which a dying person could have expected to survive
  • YPLL is a type of mortality indicator

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Years lost to morbidity refers to the time spent living with a disease or disability, which is not directly related to the concept of years of potential life lost.

 

Option C. Years lost to disability is a component of disability-adjusted life years (DALY). DALY Is BEST measure of burden of disease in a defined population and the effectiveness of interventions.

 

DALY = YLL (Years of lost life) + YLD (Years lost to disability)

 

Option D. life would account into QALY (Quality Adjusted Life Years)

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Years of Potential Life Lost (YPLL) is a measure that quantifies the impact of premature death on a population by calculating the number of years not lived by individuals who die before reaching a specified age. It highlights the significance of early mortality and its impact on society.

questions.text: Which of the following mood stabilizers causes hepatitis ? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Valproate

 

Explanation:

 

Valproate is known to cause hepatotoxicity, thus it is essential to monitor liver function tests regularly in patients taking valproate, especially during the initial months of therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lithium: Lithium is not hepatotoxic. It primarily affects the kidneys (nephrogenic diabetes insipidus) and thyroid (causing hypothyroidism). Common side effects include tremor, weight gain, and cognitive dulling.

 

Option C. Carbamazepine: Carbamazepine is associated with hematologic toxicities (like agranulocytosis and aplastic anemia), SIADH, and Stevens-Johnson syndrome. It is not commonly hepatotoxic, although rare hepatic dysfunction has been reported.

 

Option D. Topiramate: Topiramate is not associated with liver toxicity. Side effects include weight loss, renal stones, paresthesias, cognitive slowing, and metabolic acidosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Valproate, a commonly used mood stabilizer in bipolar disorder, is associated hepatitis. Regular monitoring of liver function tests is crucial in patients on valproate therapy to detect and manage potential liver damage early.

choices.text: Both the treatments are equally effective
Neither of the treatments is effective
The new treatment is more effective than the usual treatment
The information given is not adequate to compare the efficacy of the treatments

questions.text: In a well-designed cancer study, comparable rates of remission were achieved for both a new treatment (33.2%) and the conventional treatment (32.2%). The corresponding p-value was recorded as 0.04. Which of the following statements is true regarding the study? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) The new treatment is more effective than the usual treatment 

 

  • A p-value of 0.04 (< 0.05) indicates that the results are statistically significant and there is evidence to suggest that the new treatment is more effective than the usual treatment. 
  • Although the difference in remission rates is small, it is still statistically significant, which means that the new treatment may have some clinical benefits compared to the usual treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Both the treatments are equally effective: This statement is misleading because, although the remission rates are close, the statistical analysis (p-value < 0.05) indicates a significant difference, favoring the new treatment.

 

Option B. Neither of the treatments is effective: This option is incorrect as the statement about effectiveness cannot be deduced solely from the remission rates and p-value provided; effectiveness also depends on other factors such as comparison with control groups or historical data which are not mentioned here.

 

Option D. The information given is not adequate to compare the efficacy of the treatments: While more information about the study design and other factors could be beneficial, the p-value provided is adequate under standard scientific criteria to make a preliminary comparison regarding the efficacy of the treatments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Even small differences in treatment outcomes can be statistically significant. A p-value of less than 0.05, as seen in this study, typically supports the conclusion that the new treatment offers a measurable improvement over the conventional treatment in terms of remission rates.

choices.text: Fishing and fisheries beyond territorial waters

questions.text: Which item is included in the concurrent list of the Indian Constitution? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Adulteration of food

 

The concurrent list in the Indian Constitution includes subjects on which both the central and state governments can legislate. One of the items included in this list is the adulteration of food. The legislative framework in India is divided into three lists as per the seventh schedule of the Constitution:

 

  1. Union List: Contains subjects on which only the Parliament can make laws. This list includes 100 items, such as defense, foreign affairs, atomic energy, and others.
  2. State List: Contains subjects on which only the state legislatures can make laws. This list includes 61 items, such as police, public health, and agriculture.
  3. Concurrent List: Contains subjects on which both the Parliament and state legislatures can make laws. This list includes 52 items, such as criminal law, marriage and divorce, bankruptcy and insolvency, and the adulteration of food.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fishing and fisheries beyond territorial waters: This subject is included in the Union List, meaning that only the Parliament has the authority to legislate on this matter.

 

Option C. Regulating labor in mines: This subject is also included in the Union List, placing it under the legislative jurisdiction of the Parliament.

 

Option D. Public health and sanitation: This subject is included in the State List, meaning that only state governments have the exclusive authority to legislate on public health and sanitation matters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The adulteration of food is included in the Concurrent List of the Indian Constitution, allowing both the central and state governments to legislate on this issue. The Union List and State List contain subjects exclusive to the Parliament and state legislatures, respectively.

questions.text: All of the following side effects are more commonly seen with carbamezapine than oxcarbazepine , except ?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyponatremia

 

Hyponatremia is more commonly associated with oxcarbazepine than carbamazepine. Oxcarbazepine induces this through its effect on renal handling of water by affecting antidiuretic hormone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rashes: Rashes are more common with carbamazepine due to its propensity to cause allergic skin reactions.

 

Option C. Blood dyscrasias: Blood dyscrasias, including agranulocytosis and aplastic anemia, are more associated with carbamazepine.

 

Option D. Hepatitis: Hepatitis and other liver dysfunctions are more often linked to carbamazepine than oxcarbazepine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While both carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine can cause similar side effects, hyponatremia is notably more prevalent with oxcarbazepine.

questions.text: A South Asian fruit farmer presented with fever, breathlessness, and encephalitis. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nipah virus

 

The Nipah virus is known to be transmitted by fruit bats, specifically the Pteropus species, which are commonly found in South Asia. The virus can cause severe respiratory illness and encephalitis in humans, symptoms that match the presentation in this case (fever, breathlessness, and encephalitis). The close association between fruit farming and fruit bats increases the risk of transmission, especially in South Asia where the Nipah virus is more prevalent.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zika virus: Zika virus is primarily transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes and is known for causing fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis. It does not cause severe respiratory symptoms or encephalitis as described in this case.

 

Option C. Malaria: Malaria is caused by Plasmodium species and transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes. It presents with fever, chills, and other systemic symptoms, but it does not typically cause breathlessness or encephalitis.

 

Option D. Ebola virus: Although Ebola can be associated with bats, it primarily causes hemorrhagic fever and is less associated with respiratory symptoms or encephalitis compared to Nipah virus. Also, Ebola is more commonly linked with direct human-to-human transmission or through contact with infected animals' bodily fluids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nipah virus should be considered when a patient, especially in South Asia, presents with fever, respiratory symptoms, and encephalitis, and has a history of exposure to fruit bats

choices.text: Stop the drug and proceed drug free

questions.text: A pregnant female with bipolar disorder with previous history of 4 episodes and no episode for the past 1 year, well controlled with 750 mg Lithium, now in the third trimester , comes to the psychiatrist. What is the next step in management ? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decrease dose

 

Lithium doses may need adjustment during pregnancy due to changes in renal clearance, especially in the third trimester, to minimize toxicity risks while maintaining therapeutic effects.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase dose: Increasing the dose isn't recommended due to increased risk of lithium toxicity in the later stages of pregnancy.

 

Option C. Switch to valproate: Switching to valproate is not advised due to its high teratogenic risk, especially for neural tube defects.

 

Option D. Stop the drug and proceed drug free: Stopping lithium abruptly can lead to a high risk of relapse in bipolar disorder; it's important to manage it carefully.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

During pregnancy, especially in the third trimester, it's crucial to carefully manage lithium dosage to balance efficacy with safety, avoiding both relapse and toxicity.

questions.text:
What is utilized to establish substance dependence among the options provided? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Strong desire to use the drug
  2. Priority to use drugs other than any other activity
  3. Increased tolerance
  4. Persistent use of drugs despite knowing the harmful effects
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 2, 3, 4 

 

Explanation:

 

According to the ICD-11, substance dependence is defined by the presence of several characteristic features. These include:

 

  1. Strong desire or compulsion to take the substance
  2. Impaired control over substance use, often reflected in prioritizing substance use over other activities
  3. Tolerance, meaning a need for increased doses to achieve the same effect
  4. Persistence in use despite clear evidence of harmful consequences

 

All four statements listed in the question correspond to these diagnostic features and, therefore, are used in establishing substance dependence.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: According to IMNCI, a 6-month-old child is said to have pneumonia if the child has fast breathing with a respiratory rate more than: [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 50

 

In the Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) guidelines, fast breathing is a key indicator for diagnosing pneumonia in children. The breathing rate cutoffs are age-specific:

 

  • For children less than 2 months old: > 60 breaths per minute.
  • For children aged 2 to 12 months: > 50 breaths per minute.
  • For children aged 12 to 60 months: > 40 breaths per minute.

 

Therefore, for a 6-month-old child, a respiratory rate greater than 50 breaths per minute is considered indicative of pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to IMNCI, a 6-month-old child is considered to have pneumonia if the respiratory rate is more than 50 breaths per minute.

choices.text: Caters to a population of 1-1.5 lakh
Referral centre for 2- 3 primary health centers
No sub-district and district hospitals present in the area
Should have a 100-bed facility in metro cities

questions.text: Which statement most accurately refers to the requirements for initiating an urban community health center? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Should have a 100-bed facility in metro cities 

 

U-CHC (URBAN - COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTRE)

 

An Urban Community Health Center (U-CHC) is designed to provide inpatient care and other health services in urban areas. According to the IPHS 2022 Guidelines, the requirements for U-CHCs are as follows:

 

  • 30-50 bedded U-CHC providing inpatient care in cities (>1 per 500,000 population)
  • 75-100 bedded U-CHC facilities in metros
  • U-CHC may be set up as a satellite hospital for every 4-5 U-PHCs

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient from Uttar Pradesh presented with fever, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly. Peripheral smear examination showed pancytopenia. Buffy coat examination showed macrophages laden with organisms with a kinetoplast. What is the vector for the likely disease? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sandfly

 

From the given clinical features, the most likely disease is visceral leishmaniasis or Kala azar caused by Leishmania donovani, and the vector is sandfly. A patient from Uttar Pradesh presenting with fever, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly with a smear examination showing pancytopenia and macrophages containing organisms with kinetoplasts point towards the diagnosis.

 

 

Leishmaniasis is transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly. In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh. Patients present with high fever, hepatosplenomegaly, weight loss, and emaciation. The skin becomes dry, rough, and darkly pigmented. There is anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia.

 

The parasite exists in 2 forms:

 

  • Amastigote form (also called LD bodies)- It is seen within macrophages and contains a kinetoplast.
  • Promastigote form- It is the infective form in the sandfly. The kinetoplast is seen at the anterior end.

 

Kinetoplast are non-nuclear DNA present in addition to nucleus. They consist of blepharoplast and parabasal body. Flagellum originates near the kinetoplast.

 

Diagnosis of kala-azar is mainly by demonstration of amastigotes within macrophages in tissue aspirates such as blood smears, bone marrow, splenic, or lymph node aspirate. It is the gold standard for diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tse-Tse fly: Transmits trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness), not leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Triatomine bug: Known for spreading Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis).

 

Option D. Female Anopheles mosquito: Vector for malaria, not leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visceral leishmaniasis, caused by Leishmania donovani and transmitted by sandflies, is a severe systemic disease. Recognizing its epidemiology, clinical presentation, and diagnostic features is crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment. Awareness and control of the vector, along with appropriate medical intervention, are essential in areas endemic for this disease.

choices.text: Porta hepatis and inferior vena cava
Right and left lobe of liver

questions.text: The cholecysto-vena caval line is an anatomical landmark that connects which of the following structures? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Gallbladder and inferior vena cava

 

  • The cholecysto-vena caval line (Cantlie line) considered as true mid line of liver.
  • The Cantlie line is a fictitious line that divides the liver into two parts.
  • It contains the middle hepatic vein and extends from the midpoint of the gallbladder fossa at the inferior margin of the liver to the midpoint of the groove for inferior vena cava (IC).

 

 

Anatomy on visceral surface of the liver with division into right and left lobes by the plane of Rex-Cantlie line.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Porta Hepatis and Inferior Vena Cava: The porta hepatis, often called the "hilum of the liver," is a deep fissure on the inferior surface of the liver where several key structures, including the portal vein, common hepatic duct, and hepatic artery, enter or leave the liver. Though the porta hepatis is an essential landmark in liver anatomy and surgery, it's not associated with the cholecysto-vena caval line.

 

Option C. Caudate Lobe and Quadrangular Lobe: There isn't a distinct "quadrangular lobe" in the human liver. The liver has main lobes named right, left, caudate, and quadrate lobes. The caudate and quadrate lobes are smaller lobes situated on the liver's inferior surface. While they have importance in liver anatomy, they don't define the cholecysto-vena caval line.

 

Option D. Right and Left Lobe of Liver: On the Diaphragamatic surface Tthe human liver is typically divided into a larger right lobe and a smaller left lobe by the falciform ligament (anteriorly). The cholecysto-vena caval line helps delineate the boundary between the right and left lobes when viewed posteriorly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cholecysto-vena caval line is an imaginary line drawn from the fundus of the gallbladder to the point where the inferior vena cava (IVC) pierces the diaphragm. It roughly demarcates the boundary between the right and left lobes of the liver, especially when viewed from behind (posterior view).

questions.text: A psychotic patient developed voluntary purposeless movements and was once observed to be standing still for hours with waxy flexibility and negativism. What is the appropriate medical management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lorazepam

 

The patient's presentation suggests catatonia, which can manifest with features like waxy flexibility, negativism, and purposeless movements.

 

Lorazepam is a first-line treatment for catatonia. It often provides rapid relief of symptoms.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Haloperidol is an antipsychotic that can be used in psychotic disorders, but it is not the first-line treatment for catatonia. Additionally, antipsychotics might exacerbate or even induce catatonia.

 

Option C. Clonidine and Option D. Propranolol are not used as primary treatments for catatonia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Catatonia is a neuropsychiatric syndrome that can manifest with features like waxy flexibility, negativism, and purposeless movements. Lorazepam is a first-line treatment for catatonia and can provide rapid symptom relief. ECT is considered to be the treatment of choice.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 59, 67.

questions.text: Which of these methods relies on behavioral sciences? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Management by objective

 

Management by objective (MBO) is a technique based on behavioral sciences. It was developed by Peter Drucker in the 1950s and emphasizes the importance of setting clear goals and objectives that are aligned with organizational goals, and then measuring progress towards achieving those objectives.

 

MBO is based on the idea that individuals are motivated by the achievement of goals and that they perform better when they know what is expected of them. The technique involves a participatory process where employees are involved in setting their own goals and objectives, which are then reviewed and evaluated by their managers. This approach is intended to improve communication and collaboration within organizations, and to help employees feel more engaged and motivated in their work.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decision making:  This can rely on both behavioral sciences and quantitative methods, but in the context of management and organizational processes, it often involves analytical and quantitative approaches.

 

Option B. Systems analysis:  This is a quantitative method used to understand and analyze complex systems and processes, often involving mathematical models and simulations.

 

Option C. Network analysis:  This is a quantitative method used to plan and control complex projects, involving techniques like PERT (Program Evaluation and Review Technique) and CPM (Critical Path Method).

 

Educational Objective:
